content: The Act may be cited as the "10,000 Trained by 2010 Act." The National Science Foundation is recognized for its role in enhancing the country's information infrastructure. With automation advancing in healthcare, the industry will rely on NSF-funded researchers for information processing. NSF's research and assistance are crucial for preparing the workforce to leverage advanced technology. In 2000, 136,000 Americans were employed in information management. In 2000, 136,000 Americans were employed in information management in the healthcare industry, with a projected growth of 49 percent by 2010. There is no systematic plan for implementing information tools and ensuring the healthcare workforce can transition to the information age. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the National Science Foundation. The term "information" pertains to healthcare information. The term "institution of higher education" is defined as per section 101 of the Higher Education Act of 1965. SEC. 4. NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION RESEARCH. The Director, in consultation with other Federal agencies, awards grants for research on innovative approaches to improve information systems, including information studies, population informatics, translational informatics, and data security. Grants are merit-reviewed and competitive, with authorized appropriations of $3.5 million for 2008, $3.6 million for 2009, and $3.7 million for 2010. The Director awards grants for research on innovative approaches to improve information systems, including population informatics and data security. Grants are merit-reviewed and competitive, with authorized appropriations of $3.7 million for 2010 and $3.8 million for 2011. Multiyear grants are awarded to institutions of higher education to establish Centers for Informatics Research. The Centers for Informatics Research aim to conduct cutting-edge, multidisciplinary research in information technology. Institutions seeking funding must submit applications detailing research projects and promoting collaboration among professionals from different disciplines. The Center for Informatics Research aims to increase the number of information researchers and professionals by evaluating applications based on innovative approaches, research experience, and collaboration capacity. The National Science Foundation will provide funding for the Center for Informatics Research to support undergraduate and graduate students in information research. The Center is encouraged to partner with government laboratories or for-profit/non-profit entities for research collaboration. An annual meeting will be held to promote collaboration among Centers. Authorization of appropriations includes $4,500,000 for fiscal year 2008. The Center for Informatics Research will receive funding from the National Science Foundation for undergraduate and graduate students in information research. Funding amounts are set at $4,500,000 for fiscal year 2008, $4,600,000 for fiscal year 2009, $4,700,000 for fiscal year 2010, and $4,800,000 for fiscal year 2011. The National Science Foundation will provide funding for information programs through the Center for Informatics Research. Funding amounts are set at $4,500,000 for fiscal year 2008, $4,600,000 for fiscal year 2009, $4,700,000 for fiscal year 2010, and $4,800,000 for fiscal year 2011. The Director will establish a program to award grants to institutions of higher education to improve undergraduate and master's degree information programs, increase student enrollment in information fields, provide industry experience, and utilize distance learning. Grants will be awarded on a competitive basis for activities enhancing program abilities. The Director will award grants to institutions of higher education to enhance information education programs, including curriculum development, degree programs, research opportunities, and equipment acquisition for student instruction. The Director awards grants to institutions for enhancing information education programs, including curriculum development, research opportunities, and student internships in government agencies or private industry. Collaboration with other academic institutions and establishing bridge programs are also encouraged. The Director awards grants to institutions for enhancing information education programs, including curriculum development, research opportunities, and student internships in government agencies or private industry. Collaboration with other academic institutions and establishing bridge programs are also encouraged. Institutions seeking funding must submit an application detailing their research and instructional capacity. The application for funding requires a description of the consortium's roles, a plan to build instructional capacity, collaborations with government or industry, and analysis of enrollment and placement data. The Director will ensure grants are awarded in diverse geographic areas and institutions of higher education. Assessment of the proposed program's success includes postgraduate evaluation of graduate school and job placement rates, as well as the program's relevance to graduate study and the workplace. The Director will evaluate the program established under this subsection within 3 years, assessing the grants' impact on increasing students pursuing degrees in information fields. Authorization of appropriations is set for fiscal years 2008 to 2011. The Director will provide grants under the Scientific and Advanced Technology Act of 1992 to improve education in information fields. Authorization of appropriations is set for fiscal years 2008 to 2011, with increasing amounts allocated each year. The House of Representatives passed the bill on June 6, 2007. Attest: LORRAINE C. MILLER, Clerk. By Deborah M. Spriggs, Deputy Clerk.
